liking just because it had Iron Man

Suit up for a feature-length

end of the first Iron Man.

VOICE (CONT'D)
Which will still be unresolved by

We've witnessed Tony Stark battle

global terrorism and his inner
demons, now prepare to see him take

VOICE (CONT'D)
And some guy with a bird.

VOICE (CONT'D)
A sequel so inferior it will
remember as soon as you walk out of

VOICE (CONT'D)
A story that ditches technology

VOICE (CONT'D)
Witness a superhero movie with just
enough Iron Man action to fill a 3

VOICE (CONT'D)
...But not a feature length film.

VOICE (CONT'D)
Instead, sit back and watch Iron

VOICE (CONT'D)
Experience the epic face off
between Iron Man and one of

dangerous modern technology ever.
Only to waste it...on a whip.

VOICE (CONT'D)
A foe with no known super powers

who somehow survives being crushed
by a car, not once, not twice, but

VOICE (CONT'D)
To defeat this madman, Iron Man's

bringing in backup, and they're all
just as boring as the rest of the movie:

VOICE (CONT'D)
Pepper Potts, an inconsistent nag

who totally cool with her boyfriend
being Iron Man...

But freaks out when he drives a
car...

VOICE (CONT'D)
Black Widow: A sexy spy shoehorned

into the movie, just to establish
her boobs for the Avengers.

VOICE (CONT'D)
Who has the skills to perfectly fit

in and pilot an Iron Man suit,
without any previous experience.

VOICE (CONT'D)
Wait, didn't Tony need like half a
movie to learn how to work that thing?

A new chapter so thin, the key to
the entire plot is resolved by a 40
his grown son would keep his old
diorama, put it in an impossible-to
reveal the chemical makeup of an
order to wrap up all loose ends.
Ugh, someone got paid to write

Oh! That guy from, um...he was in

comments.text:
Just to let people know around here about the element which tony creates 
with help of his father's design is totally logical because after Captain 
America get's frozen and when Sr. Stark searches for him he finds Tesseract 
and then he has spend his a lot of amount of time to study Tesseract. Then 
he somehow implement the atomic structure of the Tesseract on that Estate 
design he gives to Tony as "Key to the future". 
That element which Tony creates is actually the same element by which 
Tesseract is created and this is also why in Avengers when Loki tries to 
control the mind of Tony by his scepter it simply doesn't work. Because his 
scepter was also powered by the energy of same Tesseract. :)﻿
comments.author: Rahul Siyanwal

comments.text:
+Ben Culture I think Marvel has changed little bit of Loki's Character. He 
was powerful but immature in cartoon series but here he is more mature and 
cunning than Thor. And he is also way much better in politics. In Thor 1, 
he was kind of immature but after that movie his character has developed 
more than anyone. In these movie series, Loki might be able to have some 
good strength but his most powerful quality will always remain his wits.
comments.author: Rahul Siyanwal

comments.text:
+Rahul Siyanwal You just mentioned my favorite thing about Loki. He isn't 
*always* evil. Sometimes he's just ruthless about getting things done, for 
better or worse. And I think Tom Hiddleston gets that about the character.
comments.author: Ben Culture

comments.text:
+Rahul Siyanwal IDK, Loki was able to handle the Norn Stones like an expert 
in the comics storyline *Siege,* so are the Infinity Stones (Man, what was 
wrong with "Infinity Gems"? I liked that much better), are they really that 
far out of Loki's control?

comments.author: Ben Culture

comments.text:
+Der BABA Metals are elements. Aluminum, Gold, Silver, Tin... these are all 
elements on the periodic table. Things like steel and bronze are 
combinations of these elements. Vibranium is not an earth element though, 
as it's only found on earth in meteor fragments.

comments.author: Markus Schwarz

comments.text:
It was Marvel that screwed up this movie. Jon Favreau had a great idea that 
would have the villain connecting to Tony's father where Tony's father 
screwed his father over and now the villain wants to take revenge feeling 
he deserves what's his.

Instead, Marvel just said, "Naaah, we need a commercial for The Avengers. 
Just shoehorn in Black Widow, Nick Fury, Captain America's shield, etc. 
Don't bother writing a story. We just need to hype people for The 
Avengers." That's how we ended up with this crap.

Thankfully Marvel seems like they're letting writers actually write a movie 
again since Captain America 2 was one of the best written comic-book movies 
of all time.﻿

comments.text:
(Just saying) The whole point of the movie Chef directed and starring Jon 
Favreau was about how he hated how the owner of the restaurant fired him 
for trying to create his own movie (all of Iron Man 2 was basically 
directed by the higher-ups of Marvel and not  Jon Favreau) and how the 
bloggers and stuff who went to his restaurant completely insulted him when 
he was forced to make a meal that wasn't his creation at all, but the owner 
of the restaurant. Just saying, those people you insult are people too blah 
blah blah but come on he did okay.﻿

comments.text:

everywhere, including critics, that it should've won an Oscar for its story.
comments.author: OminousFlare

comments.text:
+OminousFlare Nah. Just effects. Captain America 2 wasn't nominated for an 
Oscar for best picture, writing, etc. It wasn't. Just for effects like Iron 
Man 2.

But yeah. Captain America 2 was a great movie and probably one of Marvel's 
best so far.
comments.author: Link Goron

comments.text:

story was Oscar-worthy. At least compared to the rest of the trash Marvel
